title: Romans Chapter 6 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Romans chapter 6 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Romans Chapter 6 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Romans Chapter 6.

questions.question: According to Romans 6:1, what question is asked about continuing in sin?
options: Shall we continue in sin, that grace may abound?
Can sin be ignored by believers?
questions.correctAnswer: Shall we continue in sin, that grace may abound?
questions.explanation: Romans 6:1 asks, 'What shall we say then? Shall we continue in sin, that grace may abound?' which questions if sin should be continued so grace can increase.

questions.question: What is the answer given in Romans 6:2 to continuing in sin?
questions.correctAnswer: God forbid
questions.explanation: Romans 6:2 states, 'God forbid. How shall we, that are dead to sin, live any longer therein?' rejecting the idea of continuing in sin.

questions.question: According to Romans 6:3, into what are believers baptized?
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus Christ's death
questions.explanation: Romans 6:3 says, 'Know ye not, that so many of us as were baptized into Jesus Christ were baptized into his death?' indicating baptism into Christ's death.

questions.question: What does Romans 6:4 say believers should walk in after baptism?
questions.correctAnswer: Newness of life
questions.explanation: Romans 6:4 teaches that believers are 'buried with him by baptism into death... even so we also should walk in newness of life.'

questions.question: According to Romans 6:6, what happened to our old man?
questions.correctAnswer: Crucified with Christ
questions.explanation: Romans 6:6 states, 'our old man is crucified with him, that the body of sin might be destroyed.'

questions.question: True or False: Romans 6:7 states that he who is dead is freed from sin.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Romans 6:7 clearly says, 'For he that is dead is freed from sin.'

questions.question: What does Romans 6:9 say about Christ's death and dominion?
options: Christ dieth no more; death hath no more dominion over him
questions.correctAnswer: Christ dieth no more; death hath no more dominion over him
questions.explanation: Romans 6:9 states, 'Knowing that Christ being raised from the dead dieth no more; death hath no more dominion over him.'

questions.question: According to Romans 6:11, how should believers reckon themselves?
options: Dead unto sin, but alive unto God
questions.correctAnswer: Dead unto sin, but alive unto God
questions.explanation: Romans 6:11 instructs, 'Likewise reckon ye also yourselves to be dead indeed unto sin, but alive unto God through Jesus Christ our Lord.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Romans 6:14 says, 'For sin shall not have _____ over you: for ye are not under the law, but under grace.'
questions.correctAnswer: dominion
questions.explanation: Romans 6:14 states, 'For sin shall not have dominion over you: for ye are not under the law, but under grace.'

questions.question: True or False: Romans 6:15 asks if we should sin because we are under grace.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Romans 6:15 asks, 'What then? shall we sin, because we are not under the law, but under grace? God forbid.'

questions.question: According to Romans 6:16, to whom are we servants if we obey them?
options: To whom we yield ourselves servants to obey
questions.correctAnswer: To whom we yield ourselves servants to obey
questions.explanation: Romans 6:16 says, 'Know ye not, that to whom ye yield yourselves servants to obey, his servants ye are to whom ye obey.'

questions.question: What fruit does Romans 6:22 say believers now have as servants to God?
questions.correctAnswer: Fruit unto holiness
questions.explanation: Romans 6:22 states, 'But now being made free from sin, and become servants to God, ye have your fruit unto holiness.'

questions.question: True or False: Romans 6:23 says the wages of sin is eternal life.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Romans 6:23 says, 'For the wages of sin is death; but the gift of God is eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.'

questions.question: What does Romans 6:10 say about Christ's death and life?
options: He died unto sin once, but liveth unto God
He died and lives unto sin
questions.correctAnswer: He died unto sin once, but liveth unto God
questions.explanation: Romans 6:10 states, 'For in that he died, he died unto sin once: but in that he liveth, he liveth unto God.'

questions.question: According to Romans 6:13, what should believers yield their members as instruments of?
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness unto God
questions.explanation: Romans 6:13 instructs, 'yield yourselves unto God... and your members as instruments of righteousness unto God.'

medium.title: Romans Chapter 6 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Romans Chapter 6 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with temptation to sin and asks how to overcome it. Based on Romans 6, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Let not sin reign in your mortal body
Sin shall always have dominion over you
Keep yielding to sin as it is natural
Ignore the struggle and it will go away
questions.correctAnswer: Let not sin reign in your mortal body
questions.explanation: Romans 6:12 teaches us not to let sin reign in our mortal bodies so that we do not obey its lusts. This is supported by verses 6:13 and 6:14 which encourage yielding ourselves to God and knowing sin shall not have dominion over us.

questions.question: How does Romans 6 describe the relationship between baptism and new life in Christ?
options: Baptism symbolizes being buried with Christ and walking in newness of life
Baptism is just a public declaration with no spiritual meaning
Baptism cleanses only the physical body
Baptism must be repeated often to maintain salvation
questions.correctAnswer: Baptism symbolizes being buried with Christ and walking in newness of life
questions.explanation: Romans 6:3-4 explains that those baptized into Jesus Christ are baptized into His death, symbolizing burial with Him, so that we may walk in newness of life, just as Christ was raised from the dead.

questions.question: What does Romans 6 teach about the power of sin over believers who are under grace?
options: Sin shall not have dominion over you because you are under grace
Sin has more power than grace
Grace only covers sin but does not free from it
You remain under the law and sin has dominion
questions.correctAnswer: Sin shall not have dominion over you because you are under grace
questions.explanation: Romans 6:14 clearly states that sin shall not have dominion over believers because they are not under the law but under grace, emphasizing the freedom and power grace provides over sin.

questions.question: A new Christian asks how to live a holy life according to Romans 6. What practical advice would you give?
options: Yield your members as instruments of righteousness unto God
Avoid all contact with sinning people
Focus on legalistic rules to keep from sinning
Ignore sin since grace covers it
questions.correctAnswer: Yield your members as instruments of righteousness unto God
questions.explanation: Romans 6:13 advises believers to yield themselves to God as those alive from the dead, using their members as instruments of righteousness. This practical yielding helps believers live holy lives.

questions.question: What assurance does Romans 6 give about death's power over Christ and believers?
options: Christ died once and lives forever; death has no dominion over Him
Death has power over Christ and believers equally
Christ died many times to pay for sin
questions.correctAnswer: Christ died once and lives forever; death has no dominion over Him
questions.explanation: Romans 6:9 explains that Christ, having been raised from the dead, dies no more; death no longer has dominion over Him. This assures believers of victory over death through Him.

questions.question: How does Romans 6 describe the believer's former and current status regarding sin and righteousness?
options: Formerly servants of sin, now servants of righteousness
Always servants of sin, never righteous
Servants of law, free from sin
Servants of grace, still slaves to sin
questions.correctAnswer: Formerly servants of sin, now servants of righteousness
questions.explanation: Romans 6:17-18 shows believers were once servants of sin but have been made free and now serve righteousness, highlighting the transformation in status through faith.

questions.question: What does Romans 6 say about the consequences of sin and the gift of God?
options: The wages of sin is death; the gift of God is eternal life
Sin has no real consequences; God forgives all automatically
The gift of God is temporary blessings
Sin and grace have equal rewards
questions.correctAnswer: The wages of sin is death; the gift of God is eternal life
questions.explanation: Romans 6:23 contrasts the wages of sin, which is death, with the free gift of God, eternal life through Jesus Christ, teaching a clear consequence and hope.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 6 teaches that because we are under grace, we should continue sinning to receive more grace.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Romans 6:1-2 and 6:15 strongly reject the idea of continuing in sin to increase grace, emphasizing that believers dead to sin should not live in it.

questions.question: True or False: According to Romans 6, yielding to obedience results in being servants of righteousness.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Romans 6:16-18 explains that whom we obey, we become servants of that one; obedient yielding leads to becoming servants of righteousness and freedom from sin.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "Likewise reckon ye also yourselves to be dead indeed unto ____, but alive unto God through Jesus Christ our Lord."
questions.correctAnswer: sin
questions.explanation: Romans 6:11 instructs believers to consider themselves dead to sin but alive to God through Jesus Christ, highlighting the believer's new spiritual position.

questions.question: How does Romans 6 encourage believers to deal with their 'old man' or sinful nature?
options: The old man is crucified with Christ so that sin's body might be destroyed
The old man should be pampered and nurtured
The old man can be ignored but remains active
The old man is irrelevant and needs no attention
questions.correctAnswer: The old man is crucified with Christ so that sin's body might be destroyed
questions.explanation: Romans 6:6 teaches that our old self was crucified with Christ so that the body of sin might be destroyed, enabling us not to serve sin anymore.

questions.question: What practical guidance does Romans 6 give for using our bodies in daily living?
options: Do not yield your members as instruments of unrighteousness, but yield to God as instruments of righteousness
Use your body for whatever pleases you
Avoid any responsibility for how you use your body
Only focus on spiritual matters, ignoring the body
questions.correctAnswer: Do not yield your members as instruments of unrighteousness, but yield to God as instruments of righteousness
questions.explanation: Romans 6:13 provides practical advice to not yield our bodies to sin but to God, using our members as instruments of righteousness to live holy lives.

questions.question: In what way does Romans 6 connect the believer's death with Christ to their future resurrection?
options: If we have been planted together in likeness of His death, we shall be in likeness of His resurrection
Believers die and remain dead with no resurrection
Resurrection depends on human effort, not union with Christ
Only Christ will be resurrected, not believers
questions.correctAnswer: If we have been planted together in likeness of His death, we shall be in likeness of His resurrection
questions.explanation: Romans 6:5 teaches that being united with Christ in His death also means being united in His resurrection, promising believers new life.

questions.question: How should a believer view their life in relation to sin and God according to Romans 6?
options: Dead to sin but alive to God through Jesus Christ
Alive to sin and dead to God
Living under the law without grace
questions.correctAnswer: Dead to sin but alive to God through Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: Romans 6:11 instructs believers to consider themselves dead to sin and alive to God through Jesus Christ, emphasizing a changed identity and lifestyle.

questions.question: What does Romans 6 say about the fruit of serving God versus serving sin?
options: Serving God yields holiness and eternal life; serving sin yields shame and death
Serving sin yields glory and life
Serving God leads to hardship only
questions.correctAnswer: Serving God yields holiness and eternal life; serving sin yields shame and death
questions.explanation: Romans 6:21-22 contrasts the fruit of sin, which leads to death and shame, with serving God, which yields holiness and eternal life.

hard.title: Romans Chapter 6 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Romans Chapter 6.

questions.question: According to Romans 6:4, baptism symbolizes what key spiritual reality?
options: Being buried with Christ into death and walking in newness of life
questions.correctAnswer: Being buried with Christ into death and walking in newness of life
questions.explanation: Romans 6:4 explains that baptism represents being buried with Christ into death so that, as Christ was raised, believers too may walk in newness of life.

questions.question: In Romans 6:6, what is the significance of the 'old man' being crucified with Christ?
options: It signifies the destruction of the body of sin so that believers no longer serve sin
It means literal death of the believer's physical body
It refers to Christ's physical crucifixion only
It is a metaphor for the Law being abolished
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies the destruction of the body of sin so that believers no longer serve sin
questions.explanation: Romans 6:6 teaches that the old self is crucified to destroy the body of sin, freeing believers from serving sin.

questions.question: What theological concept is illustrated by being 'planted together in the likeness of his death' and 'likeness of his resurrection' in Romans 6:5?
options: Union with Christ's death and resurrection
The practice of Old Testament sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: Union with Christ's death and resurrection
questions.explanation: Romans 6:5 uses the imagery of planting to express believers' spiritual union with Christ in both his death and resurrection, a typology reflecting new life.

questions.question: Romans 6:9 states that Christ 'dieth no more; death hath no more dominion over him.' What does this imply about Christ’s resurrection?
options: Christ’s resurrection is eternal and conquers death permanently
Christ will die again in the future
Death is a temporary state for all
questions.correctAnswer: Christ’s resurrection is eternal and conquers death permanently
questions.explanation: Romans 6:9 affirms the theological assertion that Christ’s resurrection triumphed over death forever, indicating his eternal life.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Romans 6:14 says, 'For sin shall not have dominion over you: for ye are not under the ______, but under grace.'
questions.correctAnswer: law
questions.explanation: Romans 6:14 contrasts being under the law with being under grace, emphasizing the believer's new status.

questions.question: What warning does Paul give in Romans 6:12 about sin's influence?
options: Let not sin reign in your mortal body to obey its lusts
Sin is unavoidable and should be embraced
Sin is only external and does not affect the heart
questions.correctAnswer: Let not sin reign in your mortal body to obey its lusts
questions.explanation: Romans 6:12 instructs believers not to allow sin to control their bodies or lead to sinful desires.

questions.question: According to Romans 6:16, what is the consequence of yielding oneself as a servant to obey?
options: You become a servant to whom you obey, either sin leading to death or obedience leading to righteousness
You gain freedom regardless of obedience
questions.correctAnswer: You become a servant to whom you obey, either sin leading to death or obedience leading to righteousness
questions.explanation: Romans 6:16 explains the principle that obedience determines servitude, either to sin or to righteousness.

questions.question: How does Romans 6:11 instruct believers to view themselves in relation to sin and God?
options: Dead to sin but alive to God through Jesus Christ
Masters of sin and servants of the law
Alive to sin but dead to God
questions.correctAnswer: Dead to sin but alive to God through Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: Romans 6:11 calls believers to consider themselves as having died to sin and living unto God by faith in Christ.

questions.question: What is the ultimate 'wage' of sin according to Romans 6:23, and what is contrasted with it?
options: Death is the wage of sin; eternal life is the gift of God through Jesus Christ
Wealth is the wage of sin; poverty is the gift of God
Suffering is the wage of sin; peace is the gift of God
Ignorance is the wage of sin; knowledge is the gift of God
questions.correctAnswer: Death is the wage of sin; eternal life is the gift of God through Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: Romans 6:23 contrasts the consequences of sin—death—with the gracious gift of eternal life through Jesus.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 6:1 suggests that grace encourages believers to continue sinning.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Romans 6:1 poses the rhetorical question about continuing in sin to increase grace, but the following verses reject that idea.

questions.question: Romans 6:17 mentions believers obeying 'from the heart that form of doctrine which was delivered you.' What does this reveal about early Christian teaching?
options: There was a taught doctrine emphasizing obedience and transformation
Doctrine was secret and not shared publicly
There was no formal teaching in early Christianity
Believers were expected to invent their own doctrines
questions.correctAnswer: There was a taught doctrine emphasizing obedience and transformation
questions.explanation: Romans 6:17 indicates early Christians received a specific teaching or doctrine which they obeyed sincerely, highlighting authorial intent to instruct.

questions.question: How does the metaphor of 'members as instruments' in Romans 6:13 relate to the cultural context of the ancient Near East?
options: It reflects the idea of body parts as tools to be used for righteousness or unrighteousness
It refers to musical instruments used in worship
It describes slaves as instruments of their masters
It alludes to agricultural tools common in the region
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the idea of body parts as tools to be used for righteousness or unrighteousness
questions.explanation: Romans 6:13 uses 'members as instruments' metaphorically to describe the body parts as tools for moral action, consistent with Greco-Roman rhetorical imagery.

questions.question: What literary device is prominent in Romans 6:8-10 where Christ’s death and resurrection are contrasted with the believer’s life and death?
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm
questions.explanation: Romans 6:8-10 uses a chiastic structure contrasting death and life in Christ to emphasize theological points.

questions.question: Romans 6:19 uses the phrase 'I speak after the manner of men' to explain a concept. What is Paul acknowledging here?
options: He is using a human analogy due to their fleshly weakness
He is quoting a pagan philosopher
He is referring to a legal contract
questions.correctAnswer: He is using a human analogy due to their fleshly weakness
questions.explanation: Romans 6:19 shows Paul adapting his explanation to human understanding because of the believers' fleshly infirmity.

questions.question: According to Romans 6:22, what is the fruit or result of being made free from sin and becoming servants of God?
questions.correctAnswer: Holiness and everlasting life
questions.explanation: Romans 6:22 states that freedom from sin and servitude to God produce holiness and culminate in eternal life.

theological.title: Romans Chapter 6 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Romans Chapter 6 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Romans 6:2, why should those who are dead to sin not continue to live in sin?
options: Because they have been baptized into Jesus Christ
Because they are dead to sin
questions.correctAnswer: Because they are dead to sin
questions.explanation: Romans 6:2 teaches that those who are dead to sin should no longer live in it. Being 'dead to sin' means their old sinful nature is crucified and they are no longer under sin's dominion, consistent with Colossians 3:3 and Galatians 2:20.

questions.question: What is the significance of baptism according to Romans 6:3-4?
options: It unites believers with Christ's death and resurrection
It marks entrance into the church
questions.correctAnswer: It unites believers with Christ's death and resurrection
questions.explanation: Romans 6:3-4 shows baptism represents being buried with Christ in His death and raised to walk in newness of life, paralleling the believer's union with Christ found also in Colossians 2:12 and Galatians 3:27.

questions.question: What does Romans 6:6 say happened to our 'old man'?
questions.correctAnswer: It was crucified with Christ
questions.explanation: Romans 6:6 states the old self was crucified with Christ so that sin's power would be broken, consistent with Ephesians 4:22-24 and Galatians 5:24 where believers put off the old nature.

questions.question: According to Romans 6:7, what is the result for the one who is dead?
questions.correctAnswer: They are free from sin
questions.explanation: Romans 6:7 explains that death to sin brings freedom from sin’s dominion, echoing Galatians 5:1 and John 8:36 where freedom from sin is emphasized.

questions.question: How does Romans 6:9 describe Christ’s relationship to death after His resurrection?
options: Death no longer has dominion over Him
questions.correctAnswer: Death no longer has dominion over Him
questions.explanation: Romans 6:9 declares Christ’s resurrection means death no longer rules over Him, affirming His eternal life as in Hebrews 7:16 and 1 Corinthians 15:54-55.

questions.question: What does Romans 6:11 urge believers to consider themselves as?
options: Dead to sin but alive to God
Dead to God but alive to sin
Alive to sin but dead to God
Dead to both sin and God
questions.correctAnswer: Dead to sin but alive to God
questions.explanation: Romans 6:11 instructs believers to reckon themselves dead to sin and alive to God through Jesus Christ, matching the teaching of Ephesians 2:1-5 and Colossians 3:1-3.

questions.question: What does Romans 6:12 warn believers not to let sin do?
questions.correctAnswer: Rule in their mortal bodies
questions.explanation: Romans 6:12 warns against letting sin reign in the body to obey its lusts, consistent with 1 Corinthians 6:12-20 and Galatians 5:16-17 urging believers to resist sin’s control.

questions.question: According to Romans 6:13, how should believers present themselves?
options: As instruments of unrighteousness to sin
As alive from the dead and instruments of righteousness to God
As neutral in the conflict between sin and righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: As alive from the dead and instruments of righteousness to God
questions.explanation: Romans 6:13 calls believers to yield themselves to God as those alive from the dead, using their members for righteousness, reflecting similar exhortations in Titus 2:11-14 and 1 Peter 2:24.

questions.question: What reason does Romans 6:14 give for sin not having dominion over believers?
options: Because they are under the law
questions.correctAnswer: Because they are under grace
questions.explanation: Romans 6:14 states sin does not have dominion because believers are under grace, not law, emphasizing the transformative power of God’s grace as in Galatians 2:21 and John 1:17.

questions.question: What does Romans 6:16 teach about obedience and servitude?
options: You are free regardless of whom you obey
You are servants to whom you obey, either sin or righteousness
You can serve both sin and righteousness simultaneously
questions.correctAnswer: You are servants to whom you obey, either sin or righteousness
questions.explanation: Romans 6:16 explains that obedience determines servitude, either to sin leading to death or to righteousness leading to life, paralleling John 8:34 and 2 Peter 2:19.

questions.question: What transformation is described in Romans 6:18?
options: From servants of righteousness to servants of sin
From servants of sin to servants of righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: From servants of sin to servants of righteousness
questions.explanation: Romans 6:18 describes believers being freed from sin and becoming servants of righteousness, consistent with 2 Corinthians 5:17 and John 12:26 emphasizing new identity in Christ.

questions.question: What does Romans 6:19 encourage believers to yield themselves to?
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness unto holiness
questions.explanation: Romans 6:19 urges believers to yield their members as servants to righteousness leading to holiness, echoing 1 Thessalonians 4:3-7 and 2 Timothy 2:21 about sanctification.

questions.question: According to Romans 6:21, what is the ultimate outcome of sin?
questions.correctAnswer: Death
questions.explanation: Romans 6:21 states the end of sin is death, affirming the biblical doctrine of the wages of sin in Genesis 2:17 and Ezekiel 18:4, and reiterated in James 1:15.

questions.question: What gift does God give according to Romans 6:23?
questions.correctAnswer: Eternal life through Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: Romans 6:23 contrasts sin’s wages (death) with God’s gift of eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord, central to Christian soteriology as supported by John 3:16 and Titus 3:5-7.

questions.question: In Romans 6:10, what is said about Christ’s death and life?
options: He died once unto sin but lives unto God
He lives and dies for sin
questions.correctAnswer: He died once unto sin but lives unto God
questions.explanation: Romans 6:10 emphasizes Christ’s unique death once for sin and His ongoing life unto God, affirming the substitutionary atonement and resurrection life found also in Hebrews 9:26 and 1 Peter 3:18.
